Award.AwardTitle: Anti-Shock Scheme Based on Dual-Membrane Structure in Capacitive MEMS Sensors and Actuators

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to develop a scheme based on
a novel dual-membrane-structure (DMS) configuration to
mitigate mechanical shocks for MEMS sensors and actuators,
which constitutes an outstanding problem in MEMS research. For
example, in order to maximize the sensitivity of an existing MEMS
microphone, the distance between the diaphragm and backplate needs
to be small and the membrane should be thin, rendering the device
particularly vulnerable to external shocks. The DMS configuration
represents an intrinsic, self-sustained, practically implementable
control scheme to counter mechanical shocks. A comprehensive
theoretical/computational/experimental paradigm based on MEMS
physics, nonlinear and synchronization analyses will be established
to validate the proposed approach.

The intellectual merit is that the strongly interdisciplinary
research will result in novel impact-protected MEMS devices with
nonlinear control. The research will lead to a new class of
MEMS sensors and actuators with ultra-reliable performances.
The theoretical/computational/experimental paradigm required to
realize the proposed research is transformative to developing
MEMS devices in biomedical, industrial, defense and homeland-security
applications.

The broader impacts are (1) to advance significantly understanding
of the fundamental dynamics of small-scale systems, (2) to enable
high-performance applications of robust MEMS devices in a broad
range of fields, and (3) to create an exciting environment for graduate
and undergraduate students in terms of interdisciplinary awareness and
skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major class of disturbances responsible for unreliable performances in microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) is mechanical shocks. Take, for example, MEMS microphones, one of the most successful commercialized MEMS sensor devices. Almost all existing MEMS microphones have a single diaphragm structure which vibrates in response to incoming acoustic signals. The vibration amplitude is detected by measuring the capacitance change between the diaphragm and the backplate. In order to maximize sensitivity, the distance needs to be small and the membrane needs to be very thin, making the device particularly vulnerable to external shocks. Existing control methods such as the electrostatic control scheme requires additional accelerometers to obtain sensed shock signal for impact control. Our question is whether an intrinsic, self-sustained, practically implementable scheme can be developed to mitigate shocks for MEMS microphones. Besides sensors, capacitive MEMS actuators are widely used in all kinds of applications ranging from resonators to switches, filters and micro-mirrors. Traditional configuration of MEMS actuators consists of a movable and deformable micro-structure and a fixed electrode, where mechanical shocks can easily cause damages such as stiction and short-circuit. It is of paramount interest to develop efficient and reliable shock-mitigation schemes for both MEMS sensors and actuators.


MEMS are fundamentally nonlinear dynamical systems, and we believe that taking advantage of the intrinsic nonlinear dynamics and implementing control circuit in these systems can result in more effective and more robust shock mitigation schemes. We proposed and investigated active and passive impact control schemes based on a novel dual-membrane-structure (DMS) configuration. We demonstrated theoretically, computationally, and experimentally that, by employing the DMS configuration, shock impact can be sensed by the MEMS devices automatically and can be efficiently mitigated by nonlinear control techniques. Moreover, the designed sensing and actuating functions of the device are  not be compromised by control or even can be slightly enhanced. Since our proposed DMS MEMS structure does not require accelerometer to sense the shock impact to obtain some feedback control signal, the control scheme can be readily implemented at low cost.


More specifically, the outcomes of the project are the following. (1) We theorized, computationally and experimentally tested a low voltage, differential scheme for harnessing mechanical shocks in electrostatic microelectromechanical actuators. (2) We showed that anti-phase synchronization can emerge in a pair of electrically coupled microelectromechanical beams, where the difference between the displacements of the two beams, or the differential signal, is robustly immune to impulsive perturbation, indicating that the system can effectively counter external disturbances. (3) We completed a systematic and general study of complex dynamics in nanosystems in terms of issues such as multistability, basins of attraction, and sensitivity of final states to small perturbations, with the finding that multistability and complicated structures of basin of attraction are common types of dynamics, and the latter can be attributed to extensive transient chaos. (4) We articulated and demonstrated an experimentally viable approach to harnessing chaos in electrostatically driven nanowire systems by taking advantage of the interplay between nonlinear dynamics and noise to exploit the principle of stochastic/coherence resonance.


The NSF project resulted in a number of publications and provided resources to train five graduate students (two on theoretical/computational and three on experimental research).
